#Background
**Language family**: Austronesian / Malayo-Polynesian / East Barito / Malagasy

#Phonology
Sources for inventory and orthography: [@rasoloson_malagasy_2005] and [@oneill_phonology_2015]

##Consonants
###Consonants by place
Bilabial: /m/, /p/, /b/, /ᵐb/, /ᵐp/
Labiodental: /f/, /v/
Dental: /t/, /ⁿt/, /d/, /ⁿd/
Alveolar: /n/, /ts/, /dz/, /ⁿts/, /ⁿdz/, /s/, /z/, /l/, /r/
Rhotic: /tʳ/, /ɳtʳ/, /dʳ/, /ɳdʳ/
Velar: /ŋ/, /k/, /ᵑk/, /g/, /ᵑg/
Glottal: /h/

###Consonants by manner
Nasal: /m/, /n/, /ŋ /
Stop: /p/, /b/, /ᵐb/, /ᵐp/, /t/, /d/, /ⁿt/, /ⁿd/, /ts/, /dz/, /ⁿts/, /ⁿdz/, /tʳ/, /ɳtʳ/,  /dʳ/,  /ɳdʳ/, /k/, /ᵑk/, /g/, /ᵑg/
Fricative: /f/, /v/, /s/, /z/, /h/
Lateral: /l/
Trill: /r/

##Vowels
Front close: /i/
Back close: /u/
Front mid: /e/
Back mid: /o/
Central open: /a/

B; b; /b/

G; g; /g/

#Rules
-Stops become prenasalized when preceded by a nasal of the same place.
-Alveolar stops are rhotacized when followed by /r/
-/a, u, i/ are reduced to [ə, ʷ, ʲ] after a stressed syllable.
-Spirants become stops in possessive and verbal constructions, reduplication, and compounding. 

## Lenition
Velar consonants are palatalized after a front vowel
